awd_titl_txt: Large Non-Semisimple Categories in Representation Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project in representation theory, which is the study of symmetries of (physical) systems. The simplest manifestation of representation theory is in dimensional analysis, as in "the way to combine a distance L and a time T into a quantity with dimension velocity is to take L/T;" in this example, rescaling the units of measure becomes a symmetry. In general, analyzing symmetries of physical systems leads to a very fine-grained analysis of how different components of a system may interact. Classical representation theory gives simple and beautiful results by focusing on the question of decomposing systems into components that do not interact between themselves (semisimplicity). Another way to decompose systems is to create a hierarchy of components, with "larger" components affecting "smaller" components, but no interaction in the other direction (as in a particle with negligible mass orbiting a planet). Nowadays many examples are known of types of symmetry for which we can obtain a complete description of possible hierarchies forced by these symmetries. This project will develop new ways to understand these hierarchies and the resulting interactions.

In more detail, the main goal of this project is to study large categories appearing in representation theory of Lie superalgebras, algebraic supergroups, and infinite-dimensional Lie algebras, focusing on applications to the theory of abstract tensor categories. Key objectives include the construction of particular large limits of categories of representations, describing them as universal (in a certain sense) tensor categories, and extracting from universality a detailed description of these categories of representations. Via these connections with large tensor categories, categorification, and duality, this work aims to contribute to the solution of longstanding classical questions about representations of supergroups, such as the computation of characters, dimension formulae, and Kazhdan--Lusztig theory. A second goal of the project is geometric: to generalize the theory of spherical varieties to the super case. The theory of spherical varieties is a beautiful mix of algebraic geometry and representation theory. The question of developing an analogous theory for supergroups is complicated because of the lack of semisimplicity. Finally, questions of harmonic analysis, such as decomposing the space of functions and describing the spectra of invariant differential operators, are essential in modern theoretical physics. A third goal of the project is to develop an approach to these questions via theory of supersymmetric polynomials and supergeometry.

por.por_cntn:
Representation theory is a mathematical tool for studying symmetry. Supergroups, tensor categories and infinite-dimensional Lie algebras are important concepts in modern representation theory and have application in other areas of mathematics and theoretical physics.  

The goal of the project was to develop new tools in representation theory of infinite-dimensional Lie algebras, obtained as limits of classical Lie algebras and superalgebras, to use Schur-Weyl-type duality between infinite-dimensional Lie algebras and superalgebras to solve long standing open problems in representation theory of superalgebras. The other goal was to construct universal tensor categories using stable patterns in representation theory. The major outcomes of this project include the following results of PI and her collaborators:

-Generalization of Bernstein-Gelfand-Gelfand category O to  direct limits of classical Lie algebras and developed Kazhdan-Lusztig theory in this setting.

-Construction of tensor category of representations of direct limits  of Lie superalgebras of type Q, computation of the socle filtration of injective modules.

-Construction of abelian envelopes of Deligne categories GL(t) using limits of categories of representations of general linear supergroups, proof of uniqueness and universal property of those abelian envelopes, existence of highest weight structure.

-Computation of the socle filtration of tensor representations of SL(infinity) using its categorical action on the category O for GL(m|n).

-Using the categorical action of SL(infinity) on the Deligne categories PI proved new results about tensor product of two Fock representations.

-Description of the category of integrable modules over affine Lie superalgebras in terms of quivers with relations, computation of Duflo-Serganova functors on simple integrable modules.

-Developing theory of Gelfand-Tsetlin modules for general linear supergroups.

-Description of categories of representations of simple Jordan superalgebras in terms of quivers with relations.

-Solving  Capelli eigenvalue problems for symmetric superspaces  and establishing connection with shifted super Jack polynomials and factorial Schur Q-polynomials.

-Description of the character ring of the periplectic supergroup.

In collaboration with C. Gruson PI wrote a textbook on representation theory intended for graduate
students.


PI gave several lectures for middle and high school students at Berkeley Math Circle, supervised research projects of undergraduate and graduate students. Several young female mathematicians were collaborating with PI on the project.
